1.title: Melania Trump vs. Michelle Obama: Public opinion
1.plot: What do Americans think about first lady Melania Trump and former first lady Michelle Obama? AEI's Karlyn Bowman breaks down the polling data.

2.title: China's strategy to gain power in Asia
2.plot: China has been able to gain a significant foothold of power in Southeast Asia without starting an open conflict with the United States. AEI's Oriana Skylar Mastro breaks down the strategies that have put China in this advantageous position.

3.title: Venezuela: Guaidó vs Maduro
3.plot: Maduro's dictatorship in Venezuela has crushed the protests of the Venezuelan people time after time. Will today's pro-democracy protesters finally have a fighting chance? AEI's Roger F. Noriega explains.

4.title: The American dream: Is it still alive?
4.plot: People in the United States still strive to attain the "American dream." But what is it, and is it still attainable? AEI's Samuel J. Abrams explains using analysis from the AEI Survey on Community and Society.

5.title: Internet privacy legislation
5.plot: California's internet privacy regulations threaten to Balkanize American online commerce into a mishmash of 50 separate state regimes. AEI Visiting Scholar Roslyn Layton explains.

6.title: Iranian Revolution: 40 years later
6.plot: AEI's Kenneth M. Pollack explains the dramatic and ongoing impact that the Iranian Revolution had on the Middle East and the United States.

1.title: SOTU 2016: Rethinking Obama's job growth policies
1.plot:
Know what this is about?
 Be the first one to add a plot.

2.title: SOTU 2016: What the President left out on trade
2.plot:
Know what this is about?
 Be the first one to add a plot.

3.title: SOTU 2016: Education policy beyond the Obama Administration
3.plot:
Know what this is about?
 Be the first one to add a plot.

4.title: SOTU 2016: Reimagining American strength in the world
4.plot:
Know what this is about?
 Be the first one to add a plot.

5.title: What New Hampshire means for the anti-establishment presidential candidates
5.plot: After crushing victories by Trump and Sanders in the New Hampshire primaries, it looks like there could be a presidential race between two anti-establishment candidates. AEI Visiting Fellow, Ramesh Ponnuru, explains the impact of their victories and how the Democratic and Republican parties could respond.

6.title: Assessing Antonin Scalia's legacy
6.plot: How will Justice Antonin Scalia be remembered? AEI Resident Fellow Jonah Goldberg explains how Scalia always kept future generations of legal scholars in mind when interpreting the Constitution.

7.title: How will Scalia's death affect the 2016 election?
7.plot: How will the upcoming fight on Capitol Hill over Scalia's Supreme Court seat bleed into the 2016 presidential race? AEI Resident Fellow Jonah Goldberg explains how Scalia's passing dramatically raises the stakes of the election.

8.title: How celebrity trumps the political establishment
8.plot: How have Donald Trump and Bernie Sanders defied the odds in the 2016 presidential election? Jonah Goldberg explains why the political establishment has crumbled in the face of celebrity power.

9.title: The run up to Super Tuesday
9.plot: What can we expect for Hillary, Bernie, Trump, Cruz, and Rubio in the run up to Super Tuesday? Jonah Goldberg explains how the Republican establishment's strategy must change after Tuesday's primaries and caucuses.

10.title: Who are the Kurds?
10.plot: The Syrian Civil War has made Kurdistan a top story from CNN to Facebook. But who are the Kurds? While they claim that they are the "largest people without a nation", AEI Resident Scholar Michael Rubin explores whether or not they are truly a united community.

11.title: Is it time for an independent Kurdistan?
11.plot: Will Kurdistan become an independent nation or remain a part of Iraq, Iran, Syria, and Turkey? AEI Resident Scholar Michael Rubin explores a third alternative that is already being pursued.

12.title: The historic potential of Obama's Cuba trip
12.plot: "Let Cubans vote." Those three words, spoken by President Obama on his planned trip to Cuba, could unite all Americans-including those Americans in neighboring countries-behind a worthy cause. Will a man elected promising "hope and change" advance those objectives in a country where they are genuinely needed?

13.title: Can American leadership help the Cuban people?
13.plot: President Obama's visit to Cuba comes as the winds of change have shifted toward freedom, away from the authoritarian populism promoted by the Castro brothers for 60 years. After a year of indulging the Castro regime and getting nothing in return, the President can vindicate his outreach to Cuba with three simple words: "Let Cubans vote."

14.title: What can the West learn from Putin's "withdrawal" from Syria?
14.plot: What is the Putin doctrine, and how does the "withdrawal" from Syria shed light on the Russian leader's foreign policy objectives?

15.title: What is the strategy behind Putin's drawdown in Syria?
15.plot: There's more to Vladimir Putin's Syria drawdown than meets the eye. AEI Director of Russian Studies Leon Aron explains how Syria is a crucial factor in the Russian leader's strategic calculus with the West.

16.title: Does the popular vote matter with the electoral college and superdelegates?
16.plot: What's the point of a popular vote when superdelegates and the electoral college appear to have final say over our elections? AEI Resident Scholar Norm Ornstein explains in 60 seconds.

17.title: How do millennials see US foreign policy?
17.plot: How do millennials' views on US foreign policy differ from their parents and grandparents' generations? AEI Resident Fellow Phillip Lohaus examines whether or not there has been a fundamental shift in the way young Americans view the role of the United States in global affairs.

18.title: How will Brexit affect the UK?
18.plot: What would be the economic and political effects of the UK leaving the European Union? A sterling crisis and new calls for Scottish independence would be only two of the immediate problems facing the UK argues AEI Resident Fellow Desmond Lachman.

19.title: Will Brexit derail the European economic recovery?
19.plot: How would Brexit affect the European economy? AEI Resident Fellow Desmond Lachman breaks down the repercussions to the EU economy as well as the political domino effect a British exit could start.

20.title: Brexit: Why the United Kingdom should "Vote Leave"
20.plot: Is Brexit the last chance for the United Kingdom to regain their sovereignty? AEI Senior Fellow John Bolton explains why he thinks the UK should vote to leave the European Union.

21.title: Will Brexit cause a global recession?
21.plot: Would Brexit spark an economic recession that would spread from Europe throughout the world economy? AEI Resident Fellow Desmond Lachman explores how a British withdraw from the UK could affect global markets...in 60 Seconds.

22.title: Brexit: Why "Vote Leave" will make Europe safer
22.plot: Could Brexit start a trend that would lead to a safer Europe? AEI Senior Fellow John Bolton argues that a Europe of sovereign nations would tackle the refugee crisis and terrorism more effectively than the EU.

23.title: Prisoner reentry and why we should care
23.plot: In the United States, over two-thirds of people who leave prison find themselves behind bars again within three years. AEI Resident Fellow Gerard Robinson explores a program in Texas that has been a major success in keeping former inmates out of prison and reintegrating them into society.

24.title: Could there still be a contested Republican convention?
24.plot: After Trump's recent sweep of primaries, is there still a chance for a contested GOP convention this July? AEI Resident Fellow Michael Barone explores the strategies of the three remaining GOP candidates.

25.title: Could there still be a contested Democratic convention?
25.plot: Does Hillary Clinton have the Democratic nomination locked down, or could Bernie Sanders pull off an upset in July? AEI Resident Scholar Norm Ornstein explains how Sanders' delegate count and ardent supporters could play a major role at the upcoming convention.

26.title: The secret agreement that designed the modern Middle East
26.plot: A secret deal between a British and a French diplomat during the First World War created the borders of the modern Middle East. AEI Resident Scholar Michael Rubin explains how the deal was drawn up behind closed doors and became the "Wikileaks scandal of the early twentieth century" after it was exposed by the Bolsheviks later in the war.

27.title: Corruption and impeachment in Brazil
27.plot: Why are so many calling for the impeachment of Brazilian President Dilma Rousseff? AEI Visiting Fellow Roger Noriega breaks down a myriad of scandals that resulted in calls for her removal, but argues that it was Rousseff's unsustainable economic policies that ultimately led her to lose the faith of the Brazilian people.

28.title: Modinomics after two years
28.plot: When he took office two years ago, Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi was heralded as a dynamic economic reformer. But has he succeeded in helping India reach its full economic potential? AEI Resident Fellow Sadanand Dhume breaks down Modi's greatest successes, shortcomings, and future goals...in 60 seconds.

29.title: Sykes-Picot: Would redrawing the borders improve the Middle East?
29.plot: A secret deal between a British and a French diplomat during World War I designed the borders of the modern Middle East. Now that the 100th anniversary of the Sykes-Picot Agreement is upon us, many people are calling for a revision of the century-old imperialist borders, but would redrawing the borders help the Middle East, or would it just be Imperialism 2.0?

30.title: Introducing the universal basic income
30.plot: The concept of universal basic income has become increasingly more prominent over the years; however, many people are unaware of what the term actually means. AEI scholar, Charles Murray introduces the idea behind a universal basic income and how it would be applied to our current society to benefit Americans nationwide.

31.title: Could the United States afford a universal basic income?
31.plot: One of the more common questions asked regarding universal basic income, is whether or not we can afford it. AEI scholar, Charles Murray explains the costs behind the program and how it compares to the current system.

32.title: The moral case for universal basic income
32.plot: Charles Murray explains the morality behind a universal basic income, and how the program would encourage a more happy and free way of life.

33.title: Would a universal basic income discourage people from working?
33.plot: A common rebuttal to universal basic income is that people would simply stop working and collect a check from the government. Charles Murray explains how his approach to UBI still incentivizes work.

34.title: What would be the immediate effects of a universal basic income?
34.plot: What would happen if the United States provided guaranteed base pay? AEI's W.H. Brady Scholar Charles Murray argues that a universal basic income will help to end many different types of poverty in America.

35.title: What is Net Neutrality?
35.plot: On June 14, 2016, a federal court upheld the FCC's net neutrality rules. But what is net neutrality, and how does it affect the Internet, businesses, and consumers? AEI fellow Mark Jamison explains.

36.title: Who was behind the attempted coup in Turkey?
36.plot: Who was behind the Turkish military's attempted coup on July 15, 2016? While there are no firm answers yet, AEI Resident Scholar Michael Rubin explores the three main suspects in 60 seconds.

37.title: Pokémon Go versus the FCC's net neutrality rules
37.plot: With its "T-Mobile Tuesdays" promotion, T-Mobile is giving customers free data for Pokémon Go. But does that defy net neutrality? AEI Visiting Fellow Roslyn Layton describes how the FCC's rules impact zero-rating-the practice of giving away free data for certain applications.

38.title: What will the coup attempt mean for US-Turkey relations?
38.plot: What will be the implications of the attempted coup on US-Turkey relations? Michael Rubin explores Turkish media accusations that the US was complicit in the coup and draws parallels to Iranian tensions with the Carter administration in the 1970s.

39.title: Iran vs. ISIS vs. the USA
39.plot: Iran might seem like a natural ally for the US in the fight against ISIS, but the enemy of your enemy is not necessarily your friend.

40.title: Consequences of the failed Turkish coup
40.plot: What are the biggest consequences of the failed coup in Turkey? Michael Rubin describes how Erdogan has launched a crackdown that would make even Vladimir Putin blush, the results of which could have profound impacts on the West's fight against ISIS as well as Turkey's relations with the US and EU.

41.title: Beyond the Rio Olympics: Why Brazilians are competing for the future
41.plot: The Rio Olympics were supposed to be a "coming out party" for Brazil showcasing the economic and energy sector strength of the diverse South American power, but political scandal and a teetering economy have tempered those expectations. Just as the Olympic athletes expect a fair competition at the games, AEI Visiting Fellow Roger Noriega argues that the Brazilian people also deserve to compete fairly in the Brazilian economy.

42.title: Debunking the feminist wage gap myth
42.plot: Is there any truth to feminists' assertion that women make less money than men in the same jobs? Factual Feminist and AEI Resident Scholar Christina Hoff Sommers sheds some light on the gender wage gap controversy.

43.title: Why does the South China Sea matter to the USA?
43.plot: In recent years China has expanded its control over the South China Sea, but why does that matter to the United States? AEI Research Fellow Michael Mazza explains the strategic role that the South China Sea plays in the USA's foreign, defense, and economic policies.

44.title: The "unproductive production" fueling China's GDP
44.plot: AEI Resident Scholar Derek Scissors argues that the massive growth of the Chinese economy has come with the cost of massive debt.

45.title: What does China want in the South China Sea?
45.plot: Unlike China's neighbors, the South China Sea's islands are not within China's exclusive economic zone. So what do they want there? AEI Research Fellow Michael Mazza describes China's motivations for its claims in the waters near the Philippines and Vietnam.

46.title: The Hague ruling's effect on the South China Sea
46.plot: The Hague's Permanent Court of Arbitration recently ruled against China's claims in the South China Sea. What happens now? AEI Research Fellow Michael Mazza explains.

47.title: Iran nuclear deal: Has Iran honored the terms of the nuke deal?
47.plot: One year after the Iran nuclear deal, have they kept their word? AEI Resident Fellow J. Matthew McInnis argues that, while they have kept to the technical terms of the deal, they are not adhering to the spirit of the agreement.

48.title: How likely is war in the South China Sea?
48.plot: With tensions rising in China, the Philippines, and Vietnam, how likely is war in the South China Sea? AEI Research Fellow Michael Mazza surveys the factors that could lead to armed conflict in South East Asia.

49.title: Should Americans be scared about Chinese investments?
49.plot: With a growing number of American assets being sold to Chinese investors, many are concerned about China's expanding presence. Derek Scissors describes the reality of the situation, and what Chinese investments mean for Americans.

50.title: Iran nuclear deal: Will Iran allow foreign investment?
50.plot: One year after the nuclear deal, it remains unclear that Iran will take full advantage of potential foreign investments. AEI Resident Fellow J. Matthew McInnis explores how deep wounds left by colonialism make many Iranians skeptical of allowing foreign companies to invest in Iran.

51.title: Colombian peace deal: Why "no" is not voting against peace
51.plot: A peace deal brokered by Colombian President Juan Manuel Santos was rejected by the Colombian people. Do they want war instead? Roger Noriega, AEI Visiting Fellow, explains that voting "no" on the peace deal is not against peace, but is actually in favor of justice.

52.title: Yemen War: A proxy war for Iran and Saudi Arabia
52.plot: The Yemeni Civil War continues as both Iranian and Saudi influences within the borders grow stronger. AEI Research Fellow, Katherine Zimmerman, explains how the war's outcome could affect the Middle East.

53.title: Colombian peace deal: What is the FARC?
53.plot: On October 2, the Colombian people voted to reject a peace deal between the Colombian government and the FARC. But who are the FARC? AEI Visiting Fellow Roger Noriega explains that the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia (FARC) is a rebel group founded to undermine democracy in Columbia. As both parties return to the negotiating table in search of a new peace agreement, Noriega explains the group's criminal and political history and what a peace deal would mean for Colombia.

54.title: Yemen War: How the conflict affects the United States
54.plot: The war in Yemen is not simply a regional conflict, but will also affect United States security interests. Katherine Zimmerman, AEI Research Fellow, explains how the proxy war in Yemen between Saudi Arabia and Iran has implications for al Qaeda, ISIS, and the war in Syria.

55.title: The Venezuelan collapse: How the US could respond
55.plot: Will President Obama preside over the consolidation of a dictatorship in Venezuela? Or will the US help democracy flourish? Roger Noriega, AEI Visiting Fellow, analyzes what the United States could do.

56.title: Why did Hillary Clinton lose the election?
56.plot: With everything from third-party voters to the electoral college being blamed for Hillary's loss in the 2016 election, AEI Resident Fellow Michael Barone explores the real reasons behind Trump's victory over Clinton.

57.title: Trump's first 100 days: How could the Democrats respond?
57.plot: Republicans have majorities in the House of Representatives and the Senate, and Donald Trump is president. Can Democrats do anything to stop the GOP? AEI Resident Fellow Michael Barone examines the options for Democrats during Trump's first 100 days.

58.title: Colombian peace deal: Could the FARC ever take power in Colombia?
58.plot: On November 30, the Colombian congress ratified a revised peace deal between the Colombian government and the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia (FARC) rebel group. An earlier agreement between the two parties was rejected by Colombian citizens in an October 2 referendum. The new deal retains many controversial elements of the rejected deal, including guaranteed congressional representation for the FARC. AEI Visiting Fellow Roger Noriega explains some Colombians' suspicion that the FARC will use its new position and illicit drug income to undermine Colombian ...

59.title: How will Democrats fare in the 2018 midterm elections?
59.plot: With Hillary Clinton's unexpected loss to Donald Trump for the presidency, how will Democrats fare in the 2018 midterm elections? AEI Resident Fellow Michael Barone analyzes the possibilities for Republicans and Democrats running for congress in 2018.

60.title: Russian hacking: Did Putin specifically target Hillary Clinton?
60.plot: Did Vladimir Putin specifically target Hillary Clinton through a Russian email hack? Or was she a convenient target for a greater goal? AEI Resident Scholar Leon Aron explains.

1.title: Obama's legacy: How will Barack Obama be remembered?
1.plot:
Know what this is about?
 Be the first one to add a plot.

2.title: Should the United States shoot down a North Korean missile test?
2.plot: Recently North Korean leader Kim Jong-un claimed that his forces are preparing an intercontinental ballistic missile (ICBM) test - a capability that, once fully developed, the North Korean regime could use to threaten the United States. A crisis on the Korean peninsula could be one of the first national security emergencies facing the Trump administration. If Pyongyang tests an ICBM, should President Trump order U.S. forces to shoot it down?

3.title: How should the Senate vet Donald Trump's Supreme Court nominee?
3.plot: On Tuesday, January 31st, President Trump selected Neil Gorsuch as his Supreme Court nominee. Karlyn Bowman, AEI Senior Fellow, reviews polling data to see what Americans want in a Supreme Court judge, and how they think the Senate and the president should evaluate Supreme Court nominees.

4.title: What is an executive order?
4.plot: During his first few weeks in office, President Trump has issued executive orders at a rapid pace. Does that mean he can use them to do literally anything he wants? Peter J. Wallison, AEI Senior Fellow, explains the function and limits of executive orders.

5.title: Should Trump move the US embassy in Israel to Jerusalem?
5.plot: Despite early campaign promises, President Trump seems to have cooled on moving the US embassy in Israel from Tel Aviv to Jerusalem. AEI's Danielle Pletka weighs in ahead of Benjamin Netanyahu's visit to the US.

6.title: The New Jersey pension crisis
6.plot: With a pension crisis looming for New Jersey, AEI Adjunct Scholar Mike Lilley claims that the crisis may become a permanent fixture of life in the Garden State if the New Jersey Education Association can enshrine pensions in the state constitution.

7.title: The benefits of the Every Student Succeeds Act
7.plot: Education policy has left behind No Child Left Behind, and moved on to ESSA, or the Every Student Succeeds Act. Why is the new policy - signed into law by President Barack Obama - an improvement? Rick Hess, AEI Resident Scholar, explains in 60 seconds.

8.title: Iran's growing military power
8.plot: Iran is becoming a conventional military power. Combat units drawn from the conventional brigades and divisions of the Islamic Revolutionary Guards Corps (IRGC) have been fighting on the front lines alongside Syrian and Iraqi militias and Lebanese Hezbollah since October 2015. Iran's ability to conduct combat operations beyond its borders makes it one of a handful of states that can sustain a consistent deployment of forces abroad.

9.title: How should Trump respond to Chinese naval aggression in the South China Sea?
9.plot: One of the pressing issues facing the Trump administration is how to deal with Chinese aggression in the South China Sea. In December 2016, Beijing seized an American unmanned underwater vehicle, in a clear affront to Washington. President Trump must develop a clear, coherent strategy for dealing with China's continued maritime belligerence.

10.title: How should Trump respond if Duterte kicks US troops out of the Philippines?
10.plot: Despite maintaining a mutual defense treaty since 1951, the US-Philippine relationship has soured over the past 12 months as Philippine President Duterte has openly questioned the alliance and expressed interest in developing a closer relationship with China. How should President Trump work to maintain close ties with the Philippines? How would Washington react if President Duterte follows through on his threat to scale back the alliance?

11.title: The failure of Obama's School Improvement Grants
11.plot: According to federal analysis, one of President Barack Obama's signature efforts in education - the School Improvement Program - pumped billions of dollars into public education and yet failed to produce meaningful results for students and schools. AEI Morgridge Fellow Andy Smarick elaborates.

12.title: The problem of Big 'R' school reform
12.plot: Do massive, top-down school reforms get results and help kids? Rick Hess, Director of Education Policy Studies at AEI, doesn't think so, and calls this problem "Big 'R' school reform".

13.title: The solution of little 'r' school reform
13.plot: If onerous regulations don't improve education, what will? Rick Hess, AEI's Director of Education Policy Studies, says that empowering teachers to make decisions is the way to high-performing schools.

14.title: Venezuela crisis: A brief history
14.plot: Despite growing opposition within Venezuela, the Maduro regime has done everything it can to consolidate its power. How did we get to where we are today? AEI Visiting Fellow Roger Noriega explains.

15.title: Consequences of the Turkish Referendum (Referandum Turkiye)
15.plot: Turkey's upcoming referendum vote could determine a radical restructuring of its government and expansion of President Erdogan's executive powers. Is this a simple streamlining of government as President Erdogan claims? Or a more nefarious push towards dictatorship? AEI's Resident Scholar Michael Rubin explains.

16.title: Venezuela crisis: The world's response
16.plot: President Nicolás Maduro and his antidemocratic regime have created a dire political crisis in Venezuela. AEI Visiting Fellow Roger Noriega explains how the United States and the international community are responding.

17.title: The difference between big and little 'r' education reform
17.plot: Many schools are not performing well, but almost all teachers are rated effective. What gives? AEI's Rick Hess explains that the answer lies with how reforms are done.

18.title: Border adjustment tax explained
18.plot: What does it mean for corporate taxes to be "destination-based" instead of "origin-based"? AEI Resident Scholar Stan Veuger explains.

19.title: Le Pen vs Macron: French Election 2017
19.plot: With France's most pivotal election looming, what might a Le Pen or a Macron presidency mean for the future of the country? AEI Research Fellow Dalibor Rohac explains.

20.title: School choice: The real benefit
20.plot: Does school choice damage traditional public education? No, says AEI's Rick Hess, as he identifies the real value of school choice.

21.title: Free college benefits the rich
21.plot: One of the pillars of Bernie Sanders's 2016 presidential platform was free tuition at public universities. While it was pitched as a way to help lower income students, AEI Research Analyst Preston Cooper argues that free college helps the rich far more than it helps the poor.

22.title: Education reform: Why we shouldn't use the courts
22.plot: Should school reform come from the courts? While examples from California and New Jersey seem to indicate that judges can be instrumental in changing school systems, AEI's Rick Hess cautions against the "pleasing shortcut" of the courts.

23.title: South Korean election 2017: Challenges facing new president Moon Jae-in
23.plot: What challenges confront newly-elected South Korean president Moon Jae-in? AEI's Dan Blumenthal describes the dilemmas facing South Korea, from Kim Jong-un to a fraught partnership with Japan.

24.title: Charter school accountability
24.plot: Andy Smarick, Morgridge Fellow at AEI, argues that public schools could benefit from one of the greatest innovations of charter schools: contract-based accountability.

25.title: Iran's swarm boat tactics
25.plot: Since the signing of the Iran nuclear deal in 2015, Tehran's navy has used swarms of small boats to harass vessels of all kinds in the Persian Gulf. Why are they doing this, and what can the United States do about it? AEI Resident Scholar J. Matthew McInnis explains.

26.title: Lebron James' economic impact on Cleveland and Miami
26.plot: Cities across the United States make a big deal about the expected economic gains from professional sports teams and stadiums. But is there really any benefit? AEI Resident Scholar Stan Veuger analyses the economic impact of LeBron James on Cleveland and Miami to answer once and for all if neighborhoods around stadiums really do experience a "superstar effect".

27.title: Education reform: Beware of experts
27.plot: Be skeptical - That simple, two-word message can help create rational, critical thinkers, and can be applied to everything from law to science. in this video, Rick Hess, AEI Resident Scholar, encourages listeners to be critical of the experts in education policy - even himself.

28.title: Qatar's diplomatic crisis
28.plot: On June 5th, 2017, four Arab nations - Egypt, UAE, Saudi Arabia, and Bahrain - cut ties with Qatar. AEI Resident Scholar Michael Rubin explains why these nations have severed diplomatic relations with Qatar, and why Qatar thinks the United States will remain an ally.

29.title: Vaping: Reshaping the FDA's regulations
29.plot: Even though vaping is much safer than cigarettes, the FDA's regulations threaten to destroy the majority of the e-cigarette market. AEI Resident Scholar Sally Satel explains why and how FDA Commissioner Scott Gottlieb should change course.

30.title: Education reform: Parent/teacher partnerships - Lessons from a charter school
30.plot: Who is responsible for a student's success: parents, or teachers? AEI's Rick Hess argues that a partnership is necessary for success.

31.title: Millennials and the 'success sequence'
31.plot: Millennials are taking a dizzying array of paths into adulthood. But, according to AEI Visiting Scholar W. Bradford Wilcox, one path is more likely to lead away from poverty and to the American Dream.

32.title: Education reform: Is technology the solution?
32.plot: Does technology revolutionize schooling? Not if it isn't used the right way, says AEI's Rick Hess.

33.title: War on Poverty: Did we win or lose?
33.plot: In 1964, President Lyndon Johnson introduced the War on Poverty to "cure" and "prevent" destitution in the United States. Was the initiative successful? Arthur Brooks, President of AEI, briefly analyses the results of LBJ's flagship effort.

34.title: South Korea - United States relations: What does the future hold?
34.plot: With recently elected South Korean president Moon Jae-In favoring a shift in diplomatic tactics with North Korea, how might this affect both the North Korean regime and South Korean relations with the United States? AEI's Nicholas Eberstadt offers his perspective.

35.title: Narco crime: A serious threat to the Americas
35.plot: Transnational organized crime presents a serious threat to the United States and the rest of the western hemisphere. AEI Visiting Fellow Roger Noriega details the threats we face, and what can be done to combat them.

36.title: Trump meets Putin: How to counter Russian aggression
36.plot: With President Trump set to meet Russia's President Putin for the first time, how can he best apply pressure to curb Russia's increasing aggression? AEI Resident Scholar Leon Aron shares gives his take.

37.title: India-Israel partnership explained
37.plot: Narendra Modi made history as the first Indian Prime Minister ever to visit Israel, and the ties between India and Israel are increasingly strong. What's the story behind this seemingly unlikely partnership? AEI's Sadanand Dhume explains.

38.title: Turkey coup: One year later
38.plot: A year after the coup attempt in Turkey to depose of President Erdogan, are there any answers as to who was behind it, and what its impact on the country has been? AEI's Michael Rubin gives his perspective.

39.title: Video games vs work: Are young men choosing Xbox and PlayStation over jobs?
39.plot: According to a new economic research paper, young men are spending less time working and more time playing video games. Are Overwatch and The Legend of Zelda about to ruin the American economy? AEI's Jim Pethokoukis says no, and has the facts to prove it.

40.title: Open government: Why transparency matters for public policy analysis
40.plot: In this day and age, computational simulation models are almost always used by government organizations to determine outcomes of different fiscal policies. However, these models are secretive, and kept out of the public eye. Matt Jensen the Managing Director of the Open-Source Policy Center at AEI, explains why government transparency is vital to building the most accurate and effective simulation models.

41.title: Impeach Trump? What do the polls say?
41.plot: AEI Senior Fellow Karlyn Bowman reviews the polling data to find out who wants Trump to stay as president and who wants him to go.

42.title: Trump's approval rating: 6 months in
42.plot: Six months into his presidency, President Trump is less popular than any other president ever at this point in his tenure. Is there any good news? AEI Senior Fellow Karlyn Bowman reviews the opinion polls.

43.title: Space Corps: A new military branch?
43.plot: The House of Representatives' version of a defense policy bill mandates the creation of a new military service, the "Space Corps", by January 2019. Yet the Air Force already has a space command, and many in the military think the House's bill would create needless complexity and bureaucracy in the U.S. Armed Forces. Is the Space Corps a good idea? AEI's Mackenzie Eaglen offers her thoughts.

44.title: Leadership: Does it pay to be nice?
44.plot: While common wisdom and popular culture might tell us otherwise, AEI President Arthur Brooks thinks that niceness makes more effective leaders - and he has the data to back it up.

45.title: Trump supporters: Who are they?
45.plot: Are all the people who voted for Donald Trump the same? AEI's Karlyn Bowman reviews a study that identifies the differences between the different voting blocks that cast a ballot for the president.

46.title: North Korea's nuclear program: A history of failed diplomacy
46.plot: North Korea's nuclear threat has been 35 years in the making. AEI resident scholar Michael Rubin looks back to determine just how effective the United States' diplomatic strategy has been in deterring DPRK's nuclear weapons program.

47.title: India needs equal rights for all
47.plot: Despite its pluralist history, could religious minority rights be in danger in India? AEI fellow Sadanand Dhume shares his perspective on the state of religious law in India, and how the country should proceed going forward.

48.title: North Korea: Why do they want nukes?
48.plot: Throughout the Cold War, the United States and Russia stockpiled nuclear weapons as a deterrent to one another. Does North Korea have the same motive? AEI's Nicholas Eberstadt argues that Kim Jong-un is making nukes with the intention to use them for a political checkmate.

49.title: Tech giants vs internet startups
49.plot: Google bought YouTube. Amazon bought Twitch. Facebook copied Snapchat. Should consumers be alarmed that the tech giants tend to devour the internet's startups? AEI's Jim Pethokoukis argues that, despite alarmism from both the left and the right, there's no reason to fear that the big guys continue to acquire the little guys.

50.title: Labor Day: Are Americans satisfied with their jobs?
50.plot: Do you like your boss? Are your retirement benefits good enough? Do you get enough vacation days? AEI Senior Fellow Karlyn Bowman reviews the polls of attitudes towards work. On Labor Day, see how you compare to the average American.

51.title: Hillary Clinton's poll numbers: What happened?
51.plot: On September 12th, Hillary Clinton published her newest book, "What Happened", a tell-all about the events of the 2016 presidential election. AEI's Karlyn Bowman uses polling data to explain what happened to Hillary's chances for the presidency.

52.title: Economics: The advantages of geographic mobility
52.plot: What will it take to jumpstart the United States economy? AEI President Arthur Brooks argues that greater geographic mobility within the United States could help workers find the best opportunities.

53.title: Restoring Internet Freedom vs the digital elite
53.plot: The FCC received a record 22 million comments about net neutrality on its Restoring Internet Freedom docket. AEI visiting scholar Roslyn Layton explains why those comments shouldn't be treated like votes.

54.title: Kurdish referendum 2017
54.plot: Kurdistan might vote on independence from Iraq on September 25th, 2017. What will it mean for the Middle East and the United States? AEI resident scholar Michael Rubin explains.

55.title: DACA: Why America needs to keep the dreamers
55.plot: What are the economic benefits of deporting 690,000 people? There are none, argues AEI's Michael Strain.

56.title: DACA: What do Americans think?
56.plot: What do Americans think of DACA? AEI Senior Fellow Karlyn Bowman reviews the polling data to find out.

57.title: YouTube demonetization
57.plot: Following the advertising disruption known as "adpocalypse", YouTube has been demonetizing videos of violent video games. AEI visiting scholar Roslyn Layton argues that ending Title II net neutrality could open new doors for gamers and gaming companies to collect advertising dollars on content by partnering with ISPs.

58.title: Medicare for all doesn't make sense
58.plot: Bernie Sanders' single-payer health care proposal won't work. AEI's Jim Pethokoukis explains why.

59.title: Blade Runner curse
59.plot: Ridley Scott crafted his 1982 film "Blade Runner" with an atmosphere of paranoia about corporate power. But while it's implied that the companies in the film would endure, AEI's Jonah Goldberg explains that the nature of capitalism is for corporate behemoths to compete for survival as newer, better, more innovative businesses emerge.

60.title: Groupthink on online platforms
60.plot: Social media platforms like Twitter, Facebook, Reddit, and Tumblr can promote groupthink, and Silicon Valley companies might even perpetuate groupthink within their walls. While some have called for heavy-handed regulation as a way to protect the marketplace of ideas, AEI visiting scholar Roslyn Layton believes that greater competition in online advertising will have better results to promote speech without violating First Amendment principles.

61.title: Teachers are absent too often, and that's a problem
61.plot: A Fordham Institute study found that 28% of teachers in traditional public schools use sick days and personal leave to miss two weeks of school every year. AEI's Rick Hess criticizes teachers' unions for making excuses instead of making plans to improve teacher attendance.

62.title: Bullying kindergarteners? How not to teach social issues in school
62.plot: In a series of lessons, a prestigious private school denied kindergarteners access to their cubbies and playground equipment so that the students might learn about discrimination and segregation. AEI's Rick Hess argues that while it's important to teach children about social issues, those lessons should be delivered in a responsible and appropriate way.

63.title: Halloween: Paranormal beliefs in America
63.plot: According to AEI's Karlyn Bowman, various polls show that belief in ghosts is on the rise in the United States, even though most Americans don't think they're superstitious.

64.title: Tax reform: How would the Republican plan affect 401(k) savings?
64.plot: How would Congressional Republican proposals to change retirement savings regulations affect your 401(k)? AEI's Andrew Biggs explains.

65.title: Teacher evaluation: Just paperwork?
65.plot: When school reformers focused on revising teacher evaluations, administrations enacted well-intentioned reforms with unintended consequences: increased paperwork without improved outcomes. AEI's Rick Hess explains the problem and offers a solution.

66.title: Yemen: Would breaking up the country end the civil war?
66.plot: Before 1990, Yemen was two countries. As a civil war wages, will peace be achieved by dividing the country into northern and southern halves? AEI Research Fellow Katherine Zimmerman offers her analysis.

67.title: Uber tax in Chicago?
67.plot: Chicago's mayor Rahm Emanuel proposed a tax hike on ride-sharing services, which would hurt companies like Uber and Lyft. Should the Windy City tax successful startups in order to help fund their public transportation system? AEI's James Pethokoukis gives his take.

68.title: Thanksgiving
68.plot: Thanksgiving is a great holiday to spend with friends and family. But what if you don't feel so thankful? AEI President Arthur Brooks shares a simple strategy - backed by research - that can make you happier, even if your circumstances haven't changed.

69.title: Retirement crisis: Fact or fiction?
69.plot: Is there a retirement crisis due to inadequate retirement savings? AEI's Andrew Biggs offers his take.

70.title: Farm subsidies: How effective are they?
70.plot: Do agriculture subsidies help boost an industry in danger, or waste government funds that could be better spent elsewhere? AEI's Vincent Smith gives his take.

71.title: Islamist militancy in Africa
71.plot: There's been a rise of Islamist militancy across Africa in recent years, but can anything be done to stop them? Or are these groups too remote and weak for the west to worry about? AEI's Emily Estelle gives her take.

72.title: ISIS in Libya
72.plot: As ISIS loses ground in Iraq and Syria, it will continue to shift its focus to Libya. What kind of a threat does the group pose there, and what can be done to stop it? AEI's Emily Estelle shares her perspective.

73.title: Putin's re-election 2018
73.plot: With Vladimir Putin set to be re-elected in 2018, what do we know about where he plans to steer Russia? While Putin's election campaign promises to go in one direction, his actions tell a different story. AEI's Leon Aron gives his take on the future of Putin's Russia.

74.title: Libya: Why the United States should take action
74.plot: With a rising ISIS threat, a complicated civil war, and an abundance of players with conflicting interests, can the United States take action to end the Libya crisis and stave off a global terrorist threat? Or should the United States be involved at all? AEI's Emily Estelle shares her take on the complex issue.

75.title: Trump's national security strategy
75.plot: How do the goals of President Trump's new national security strategy compare to those of past presidents, and those he outlined as a candidate? AEI scholar Gary Schmitt gives his take on those questions.

1.title: Populism: How should economic policy respond?
1.plot: How should conservatives respond to the rise of populism from both the Trump Right and the Sanders Left? AEI's Michael Strain encourages conservatives to stick to certain traditional values, but recommends that they expand their focus to include issues they are not currently addressing.

2.title: Turkey: Is secularism dead?
2.plot: Can secular government and culture survive in Turkey? Fourteen years of rule by Recep Tayyip Erdogan has certainly damaged those prospects. AEI's Michael Rubin offers his take on what the future holds.

3.title: Turkey: Ally or adversary?
3.plot: Over 14 years of rule by Recep Tayyip Erdogan, Turkey has flipped sides from ally to adversary. What does this mean for the United States? AEI's Michael Rubin explains.

4.title: North Korea and South Korea talks: What do they mean?
4.plot: While the image of North and South Korea meeting to talk implies that perhaps there could be peace between the two nations, AEI's Oriana Skylar Mastro advises that there could be more nefarious intentions behind Kim Jong Un's sudden diplomacy.

5.title: Trump's mental health: Should psychiatrists publicly diagnose the president?
5.plot: In light of Donald Trump's notable ego and penchant for Twitter, some psychiatrists have said that the president is not fit for office. Are they right? AEI's Dr. Sally Satel - a practicing psychiatrist - says that opinions on the president's mental health have more to do with politics than sound medical practice.

6.title: Sexual harassment: What do the polls say?
6.plot: Surveys about sexual harassment reveal a variety of opinions about what constitutes harassment and how often it occurs. AEI's Karlyn Bowman reviews the polls and reveals some of the differences between how men and women think about the issue.

7.title: What is cryptocurrency?
7.plot: Plenty has been said about cryptocurrency in the past few months. Some governments want to stop it. Other people are investing in it and making a fortune. But, um - what is cryptocurrency exactly? AEI Visiting Scholar Mark Jamison explains.

8.title: Dairy subsidies: Bad for business?
8.plot: AEI Adjunct Scholar Dan Sumner advocates the abandonment of outdated, anti-competitive policies in the United States dairy industry.

9.title: Poverty: Good news for 2018
9.plot: Poverty rates have trended downward in recent years, and they look to dip even lower in 2018 and beyond, though low labor force participation remains an obstacle. AEI's Robert Doar explains.

10.title: Should you invest in bitcoin?
10.plot: The price of bitcoin has skyrocketed and plummeted over the past several months. Many are left wondering: Is cryptocurrency the investment opportunity of a lifetime, or a bubble that is doomed to burst? AEI's Mark Jamison explains what you own and what you don't when turning your dollars into cryptocurrency.

11.title: Cryptocurrency: A challenge for regulators
11.plot: World governments are anxious that they won't be able to control cryptocurrencies. Yet AEI Visiting Scholar Mark Jamison suggests that they had best get used to idea that economic relationships in the digital economy will disrupt historic approaches to regulation.

12.title: Agency fees explained
12.plot: World governments are anxious that they won't be able to control cryptocurrencies. Yet AEI Visiting Scholar Mark Jamison suggests that they had best get used to idea that economic relationships in the digital economy will disrupt historic approaches to regulation.

13.title: Janus v. AFSCME: What's next for teachers unions?
13.plot: On February 26, 2018, the Supreme Court will hear Janus v. AFSCME. What exactly does this mean for the future of teacher's unions? AEI's Nat Malkus gives some insight.

14.title: China: An end to presidential term limits
14.plot: On February 25th, 2018, the Chinese Communist Party proposed to end presidential term limits, which could allow current president Xi Jinping to rule indefinitely. What does this mean for China and the rest of the world? AEI Jeane Kirkpatrick Visiting Scholar Oriana Skylar Mastro gives her take.

15.title: War on Poverty: What it got wrong
15.plot: According to AEI's Robert Doar, President Lyndon Johnson's War on Poverty had some important successes, but it got one thing very wrong: Financial assistance from government is not a right.

16.title: School choice and localism
16.plot: After the 2016 election, some school choice advocates hoped for a huge federal choice initiative, yet a sweeping reforms from DC can hinder more effective efforts from states and local communities. AEI's Andy Smarick suggests a humbler approach to policymaking.

17.title: Ethanol's hidden costs
17.plot: Ethanol has enjoyed support from the United States government for decades. Despite the presumed benefits of ethanol, its production bears deep economic and environmental costs. AEI's Tim Carney explains why Congress should end the ethanol mandate and let ethanol compete in the free market.

18.title: West Virginia teachers strike explained
18.plot: West Virginia's nine-day teachers' strike ended when the state raised teacher pay by 5%. But, as AEI's Rick Hess explains, teacher take-home pay is only part of the story, and the strike did nothing to change the underlying dynamics that have contributed to a frustrating status quo.

19.title: 5G rollout: Regulatory hurdles
19.plot: 5G wireless service is set to make broadband internet easier to access and more competitive than ever, but regulatory hurdles might get in the way at the local level. AEI visiting scholar Roslyn Layton explains.

20.title: US-China: Trade war?
20.plot: Is the US heading for a "trade war" with China? AEI's Derek Scissors argues, to the contrary, that President Trump's initial tariffs against China won't have much impact at all.

21.title: Washington, DC, graduation scandal
21.plot: For a decade, Washington, DC, has been a national model for school reform. Then, in January, an audit showed 1/3rd of graduates should not have received diplomas. How could this have gone unnoticed? AEI's Rick Hess argues that the case of DC public schools should serve as a wakeup call for the larger school reform community, which has been heavy on cheerleading and light on skepticism.

22.title: 2020 census: A conservative case against the citizenship question
22.plot: The 2020 census will ask respondents whether or not they are US citizens. While the US Census Bureau doesn't share data with other federal agencies, many people think that it does, and critics worry that the census will go unanswered as a result. A lack of responses will drive up costs as the Census Bureau will be forced to get the rest of its data by going door-to-door. AEI's Michael Strain makes a conservative case against the citizenship question.

23.title: Russia investigation: Public opinion
23.plot: What do the American people think of the FBI Special Counsel's investigation into Russian interference in the 2016 election? AEI Senior Fellow Karlyn Bowman breaks down the polling data.

24.title: Social and emotional learning
24.plot: The push for "social and emotional learning," or SEL, could be part of a healthier vision of schooling that moves beyond America's testing mania. Yet, as AEI's Rick Hess argues, a true consensus on such an important issue will require honoring traditional values, not just progressive enthusiasms. If SEL winds up hijacked by well-meaning ideologues, a promising cause will morph into a divisive educational culture war.

25.title: US response to security threats in the Americas
25.plot: With the pending appointment of Mike Pompeo as Secretary of State, AEI's Roger Noriega explains how the Trump administration could finally take steps to address many issues plaguing Latin America.

26.title: Should big tech be regulated?
26.plot: The cries to regulate big tech have only grown louder over the last year, coming from voices as disparate as Fox News Host Tucker Carlson and Virginia Democratic Senator Mark Warner. Is it time for the US federal government to put a lid on Google, Facebook, and other tech firms? No, says AEI Visiting Scholar Mark Jamison, and he explains why.

27.title: Washington, DC, graduation scandal: A canary in a coal mine?
27.plot: AEI's Nat Malkus argues that DC is a lesson that we can't improve the lives of students or school systems, unless school leaders push our students to new heights rather than just pretending to.

28.title: Big tech using your data
28.plot: Following the Facebook scandal, many people expressed concerns about how big tech companies take advantage of their users' data to drive service consumption. AEI's visiting scholar Mark Jamison advises big tech companies to be transparent about their real business models.

29.title: Work requirements help the poor
29.plot: While some have argued that work requirements for safety net programs are "cruel", AEI's Angela Rachidi argues that work requirements can help those at risk of poverty to stay connected to the labor force and lead better lives.

30.title: Poor marks on The Nation's Report Card
30.plot:
Know what this is about?
 Be the first one to add a plot.

31.title: Big tech break up: Are Silicon Valley companies too big?
31.plot: Some world leaders, including Emmanuel Macron and Donald Trump, have had America's big tech companies in their cross hairs. Should the giants of Silicon Valley be broken up? AEI visiting scholar Mark Jamison says no, and explains why.

32.title: 2018 Inter-Korean Summit: What will happen when North Korea and South Korea meet?
32.plot: AEI's Nicholas Eberstadt argues that, if history is any indicator, breakthroughs are unlikely at the latest meeting between North and South Korea.

33.title: Putin's world vision
33.plot: According to AEI's Frederick Kagan, Vladimir Putin would like nothing more than to get the United States out of his way so he can achieve his vision of the world.

34.title: Climate change: What do Americans think?
34.plot: What do Americans think about climate change? AEI's Karlyn Bowman reviews the polling data.

35.title: Xi Jinping: China's would-be emperor
35.plot: With President Xi Jinping poised to become an emperor in all but name, China has positioned itself to expand its influence all across Asia and into the West. AEI's Dan Blumenthal explains why the US and its allies should be concerned and what they can do to push back against Chinese expansionism.

36.title: 2018 teacher strikes explained
36.plot: This spring, teacher strikes have spread across the United States. AEI's Rick Hess explains the facts behind the strikes and clarifies some common misconceptions.

37.title: Sunni v. Shia: Iran's strategy
37.plot:
Know what this is about?
 Be the first one to add a plot.

38.title: Guaranteed jobs for all Americans?
38.plot: Senator Bernie Sanders has proposed a $15-an-hour job for all Americans. AEI's Michael Strain argues that the senator's proposal would be impossible to execute and is demoralizing to workers.

39.title: Karnataka election: Is this the end of the Nehru-Gandhi dynasty?
39.plot: Following a loss in Karnataka's election, AEI's Sadanand Dhume assesses the impact of defeat on the Indian National Congress.

40.title: Kathua case: How should Hindus respond to a terrible crime?
40.plot: In January, six men allegedly drugged and raped a young Muslim girl, holding her captive and eventually murdering her. This has created a divide in India's majority Hindu community. While many people condemned the awful crime, a small but vocal minority argued that the negative news coverage is intended to defame all of Hinduism. AEI's Sadanand Dhume explains why the charge of defamation is far from the truth.

41.title: Trade war with China: American opinions
41.plot: What do Americans think about the United States's tariffs on trade with China? AEI's Karlyn Bowman looks at the polling data to find out.

42.title: Iraq's election: What does it mean for the Iraqi people?
42.plot: Despite winning a narrow plurality, Muqtada al-Sadr will have limited ability to form a governing coalition. AEI's Ken Pollack looks ahead to what could be next for governance in Iraq.

43.title: Media bias in education coverage?
43.plot: AEI's Frederick Hess discusses how his recent study found that mainstream media was more favorable to education proposals by the Democrat-led government in 2009, than the Republican-led government in 2017.

44.title: Memorial Day
44.plot: AEI's Rebecca Burgess explains that the United States remembers its core principles by remembering the specific men and women who have died to defend them.

45.title: Using exams responsibly
45.plot: AEI's Rick Hess argues that testing is a useful tool. But like any tool, it is only effective when used well.

46.title: Teacher pay: Sketching a win-win solution
46.plot: Teacher strikes swept through five states in the spring of 2018, and most of the walkouts were over teacher pay. AEI's Rick Hess delivers the facts about compensation for educators, and makes some recommendations on how to sketch a deal on teacher pay that benefits students, teachers, and taxpayers.

47.title: Child abuse and predictive risk modeling
47.plot: Can an algorithm help prevent child abuse? AEI's Naomi Schaefer Riley briefly looks at a pioneering program that uses data to help protect kids.

48.title: Media bias: How do outlets cover school choice research?
48.plot: AEI's Rick Hess studied how several media outlets reported on school choice research, and found that news coverage and editorials painted very different pictures.

49.title: Testing and the American economy
49.plot: Though America's future as an economic leader may look bright, recent PISA international test results could suggest otherwise. AEI's Eric Hanushek gives insight into how America's less-than-promising position in global academics could mean fewer skilled workers for the nation in the near future, and thus less stability as an economic trailblazer.

50.title: Turkish presidential election 2018
50.plot: On June 24th, 2018, Turks will go to the polls in an election that pits five candidates against its current president, the dictator-esque Recep Tayyip Erdogan. AEI's Michael Rubin argues that, in Turkey, the era of fair elections is long gone, and that the five opposing candidates pose zero threat to Erdogan's hegemony.

51.title: NATO summit 2018
51.plot: Despite calling NATO obsolete during his presidential campaign, President Trump seems to be doubling back on his words. AEI's Dalibor Rohac offers insight into how Trump will approach discussions with Europe at the upcoming 2018 NATO summit.

52.title: 4th of July
52.plot: What do Americans celebrate on Independence Day? AEI's Gary Schmitt explains that fireworks and barbecues commemorate much more than secession from Great Britain.

53.title: China tariffs: We can do better
53.plot: AEI's Derek Scissors proposes an alternative to tariffs to push back on China's infringements of intellectual property.

54.title: Ant-Man and the Wasp and criminal justice reform
54.plot: AEI's Stan Veuger explains that one policy intended to improve the lives of former criminals could even help a certain superhero.

55.title: Trump UK visit: Will the special relationship last?
55.plot: As President Trump prepares to visit the UK, AEI's Dalibor Rohac wonders what's so special about the "special relationship."

56.title: Imran Khan is bad for Pakistan's democracy
56.plot: The 2017 ousting of former Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif, and his subsequent imprisonment for corruption, have made Imran Khan frontrunner to be Pakistan's next prime minister. AEI's Sadanand Dhume argues that Khan's ascent to power backed by the army would weaken Pakistan's nascent democracy.

57.title: Reining in the administrative state
57.plot: The administrative agencies of the United States executive branch are gradually taking over the legislative role of Congress, adding thousands of laws each year outside the purview of Congress. AEI's Peter Wallison argues that Americans can reign in this legislative overreach by selecting the right judges at all levels of government.

58.title: Colleges are headed in the wrong direction
58.plot: America's colleges are losing support on both the left and the right, and for precisely the reasons that they should be. AEI's Frederick Hess explains.

59.title: Back to school - How to get straight answers from teachers: Tips for parents
59.plot: Parents routinely walk out of back-to-school meetings overwhelmed by a flood of impressive-sounding buzzwords, but with no guarantee that their child will be in good hands. AEI's Rick Hess provides solid questions to ask educators that will give parents clear answers and insight into their child's academic year.

60.title: Lessons from the Gates Foundation's Effective Teacher Initiative
60.plot: The RAND Corporation recently issued a study on the Gates Foundation's effort to redesign teacher evaluation. Unfortunately, the results were less than stellar - AEI's Rick Hess breaks down what went wrong with the initiative and what can be learned from it.

61.title: Impeach Trump? A sampling of public opinion
61.plot: Pollsters have been collecting data on Americans' attitudes about impeaching President Trump. Karlyn Bowman reviews what they've found.

62.title: Southeast Asia: An American strategy
62.plot: Southeast Asia is of great importance to the United States; the region is poised to become a driver of global economic growth. But a number of security challenges might hinder the region's potential. What can the United States do to help? AEI's Michael Mazza explains.

63.title: Roe v. Wade: What Americans think about abortion
63.plot: What do Americans think about abortion and the landmark Roe v. Wade case? AEI's Karlyn Bowman breaks down the polling data.

64.title: and the cost of Denver schools' free-lunch-for-all policy
64.plot: Denver students who didn't pay for school lunch, and who didn't sign up for subsidized lunch, were reminded to pay their bills with a sticker at lunch time. The stickers and other reminders embarrassed some students, and soon the policy was branded as "lunch shaming". In 2017, Denver Public Schools ended the policy by allowing all students to get free lunch - even students whose families could afford it. The bill has finally come due on Denver's free lunches. AEI's Rick Hess explains how it the solution has also come with a handful of unintended, expensive ...

65.title: Public perceptions of American veterans after 9/11
65.plot: Much to the surprise of the public, a vast number of post-9/11 US military veterans have successfully attained higher education and economic stability over the last 10+ years. AEI's Rebecca Burgess explains that despite this positive outlook for America's military, public perception has cast many of these brave men and women in a "broken veteran" narrative that hinders countless others from succeeding back on the home front.

66.title: 2008 financial crisis: How do Americans feel now?
66.plot: The 2008 financial crisis was a major blow to many Americans' faith in financial institutions and confidence in the job market. A decade later the economy has changed significantly, but have attitudes towards the financial system changed with it? AEI's Karlyn Bowman takes a look at the polling data.

67.title: Credit recovery: A second chance or a second-rate education?
67.plot: On the surface, credit recovery programs offer struggling students a second chance at success. But they can also be a way for schools to provide a low-quality education to America's disadvantaged students. AEI's Nat Malkus explains.

68.title: Abortion: How do Americans vote on a divisive issue?
68.plot: Can Americans vote for a person who disagrees with them on abortion? Karlyn Bowman reviews the polling data to explain.

69.title: Poverty in 2017
69.plot: The United States Census Bureau's 2017 report on income and poverty in the United States can present the reader with hope that poverty has indeed been reduced over the last few years. However, AEI's Robert Doar is quick to identify that this report, while useful, excludes certain key metrics describing poverty in America.

70.title: Media coverage of the 2018 teacher walkouts
70.plot: In the spring of 2018, scores of teachers across several states walked out of their schools, attracting extensive media attention. AEI's Rick Hess and RJ Martin analyzed the headlines, quotes, and content of articles on the walkouts published in five major newspapers. The results? A mix of good and bad. Rick Hess explains more.

71.title: DeVos guidelines clarify student loan forgiveness rules
71.plot: Secretary of Education Betsy DeVos has issued new guidelines on federal student-loan forgiveness in an attempt to more sensibly balance the rights of borrowers and taxpayers. Predictably, the higher-education cartel and its media allies were aghast. AEI's Rick Hess explains how the new standard is clearly better for colleges, taxpayers, and students who are willing to repay their debts.

72.title: Innovative leaders in education are overrated
72.plot: Education tends to celebrate "innovation" and "innovative leaders." Rick Hess describes why this is a mistake and what system leaders should be looking for instead.

73.title: Brazilian presidential election 2018
73.plot: Following the first round of Brazil's general election, voters are faced with the choice between right-wing candidate Jair Bolsonaro and left-wing candidate Fernando Haddad for the presidency. AEI Visiting Fellow Roger Noriega reviews the state of the race ahead of the runoff on October 28, 2018.

74.title: Nurse practitioners can save primary care
74.plot: Studies consistently show that America will face a drastic shortage of primary care doctors in the coming years, which will most hurt the poor, the elderly, and those living outside of cities where most doctors practice. But AEI's Robert Doar points to new research from Montana State economist Peter Buerhaus to show that nurse practitioners present a viable solution to this dilemma - if only state legislators would let them.

75.title: Socialism: What do Americans think?
75.plot: In a recent USA Today article, President Trump stated that "If Democrats win control of Congress this November, we will come dangerously closer to socialism in America." Is he right? AEI's Karlyn Bowman reviews polling data to discover American attitudes about socialism.

76.title: Arne Duncan's unlearned lessons
76.plot: Former US Secretary of Education Arne Duncan recently published his memoir, "How Schools Work" (Simon and Schuster, August 2018). Duncan became a matinee idol for progressive reformers during the high-flying Obama years, even as the school reform coalition unraveled and high-profile reforms like the Common Core and teacher evaluation disappointed. AEI's Rick Hess explains that Duncan's memoir offers a revealing if unintentional window into what reformers got wrong.

77.title: Education reformers should obey Campbell's Law
77.plot: When a measurement becomes the goal, it is no longer a reliable indicator of success. First observed by social scientist Donald T. Campbell, this problem corrupts data in all facets of life - from teachers who "teach to the test" to social media stars who "beg for likes". To serve America's students well, AEI's Rick Hess urges school reformers to heed Campbell's Law.

78.title: Central American migrant caravan
78.plot: AEI Visiting Fellow Roger Noriega argues that the Central American migrant caravan exploits desperate people and undermines US programs that help build a more secure and stable region.

79.title: Halloween: John Locke vs the zombie apocalypse
79.plot: It happens all the time in zombie fiction: The heroes kill the zombies even when the zombies aren't an immediate threat. So is it okay to preemptively kill a zombie? AEI's Jonah Goldberg turns to philosopher John Locke for the answer to the question that has surely plagued the consciences of generations of zombie hunters.

80.title: University funding: What does it buy for students?
80.plot: We often hear that public universities raise their tuition due to state funding cuts, and some say an increase in government funding is needed to keep tuition down. AEI's Jason D. Delisle takes a look at why tuition at many universities doesn't go down regardless of funding conditions.

81.title: Do field trips have educational value?
81.plot: Amidst the focus on reading and math scores in schooling, activities like field trips have been pushed to the side. But do they actually offer educational value? AEI scholar Frederick M. Hess breaks down some new education research suggesting that they do.

82.title: The Indian Child Welfare Act does not help children
82.plot: AEI's Naomi Schaefer Riley argues that the Indian Child Welfare Act of 1978 has adversely impacted Native American children by putting the interests of tribes ahead of kids.

83.title: Farm subsidies: Where the money goes
83.plot: As AEI Visiting Scholar Eric Belasco explains, the biggest beneficiaries of American farm subsidies are the biggest farms with the least need. Two new policy proposals might help to save money for taxpayers while still bolstering smaller farms.

84.title: Veterans and their continuing service
84.plot: One way American veterans have continued to serve has been by being politically active - by being elected to Congress and the presidency. AEI's Rebecca Burgess explains how having the voice of veterans on the legislative "front lines" is a substantive addition to our national debates.

85.title: Career and technical education: More than just a fad?
85.plot: Career and technical education (CTE) seeks to offer students a path to a valued, rewarding career. AEI's Frederick M. Hess shares hard questions raised by Tony Bennett, former Indiana schools superintendent, about what it will take for CTE to deliver on that promise.

86.title: Is there a student loan "bubble?"
86.plot: AEI's Jason Delisle reveals the true source of the student loan bubble.

87.title: Education research: The perils of narrow training
87.plot: Graduate student education training is incredibly rigorous and high caliber, so what's wrong with it? AEI's Frederick M. Hess explains why the scope of training is just as important as the quality.

88.title: Marriage and the working class
88.plot: Out of all hurdles that members of the working class face, one of the biggest setbacks is the decline of the married, two-parent home. AEI Visiting Scholar W. Bradford Wilcox examines the effects of single parents and cohabitation on working class children and how it can lead to teenage pregnancy, incarceration, and other troubled futures for children.

89.title: STEM careers: Why soft skills matter
89.plot: As AEI's Brent Orrell explains, STEM degrees can only carry American workers so far if they lack soft skills like communication and empathy.

90.title: Avengers: Endgame - Thanos was wrong
90.plot: Thanos' plan to wipe out half the universe is based in the real-world economics of Thomas Robert Malthus. So why are they wrong? Earth's mightiest hero, AEI's Michael R. Strain, gives his universe-saving explanation.

91.title: Nancy Pelosi: A second chance as Speaker of the House?
91.plot: By winning an overwhelming number of votes on November 28, Nancy Pelosi cleared a major hurdle in her quest to serve a second term as Speaker of the House. Despite the remarkable turnout, AEI's Karlyn Bowman points to recent polls that reveal a less-than-positive view of Pelosi in the eyes of Americans and rank-and-file Democrats.

92.title: Rising test scores: What do they mean?
92.plot: Do rising test scores mean that K-12 students are smarter today than ever before? No so fast, explains AEI's Frederick M. Hess.

93.title: Baby, It's Cold Outside: Too risky for the airwaves?
93.plot: In recent years, the Christmas radio classic "Baby, It's Cold Outside" has begun disappearing from the airwaves amid accusations that it promotes sexual entrapment. AEI's Christina Hoff Sommers begs to differ and explains why.

94.title: Christmas in the USA: A sampling of public opinion
94.plot: How will Americans celebrate Christmas? And do they prefer "Merry Christmas" or "Happy Holidays"? AEI's Karlyn Bowman uses polling data to answer these questions and more.

95.title: Christmas and the timeless gift of cash
95.plot: What's the perfect gift for Christmas - or any other occasion? Cash, says AEI Scholar Mark Perry.
